title: Perceptron
text:
The Perceptron Algorithm
The algorithm updates its guesses (weights) as it runs and also keeps a record of its history of accuracy. It processes one example at a time. For a given example, it makes a prediction and checks to see if this prediction is correct. If the prediction is correct, it does nothing. Otherwise, it changes its parameters do better on this example next time around. The algorithm stops once it reaches a user-specified maximum number of steps or the accuracy is 100%.

title: Perceptron
text:
Source Code
The algorithm has three main functions: fit(), predict(), and score().
We pass into fit() a feature matrix \(X \in R^{n \times p}\) and a target vector \(y \in R^n\). The function updates the weights and keeps track of the history of its accuracy. Its goal is to find a good \(\tilde{w}\) to separate the data points. Fit() utilizes the following function when updating its guesses:
\[\tilde{w}^{(t+1)} = \tilde{w}^{(t)} + y_i \tilde{x}_i\;\]
Score() and predict() compares the target variable \(y_i\) to the predicted label \(\hat{y}_i^{(t)}\). If \(\hat{y}^{(t)}_i y_i > 0\), then we do nothing because the point is correctly classified. Otherwise, we perform the update on \(\tilde{w}\).


Code
from perceptron import Perceptron

p = Perceptron()
p.fit(X, y, max_steps = 1000)

p.w

Convergence of the Perceptron Algorithm
After the perceptron algorithm is run, the weight vector \(\tilde{w}\) generates a hyperplane that perfectly separates data points from both classes on either side of it.

def draw_line(w, x_min, x_max):
  x = np.linspace(x_min, x_max, 101)
  y = -(w[0]*x + w[2])/w[1]
  plt.plot(x, y, color = "black")

fig = plt.scatter(X[:,0], X[:,1], c = y)
fig = draw_line(p.w, -2, 2)

xlab = plt.xlabel("Feature 1")
ylab = plt.ylabel("Feature 2")

title: Perceptron
text:
Nonconvergence of the Perceptron Algorithm
When the data is not linearly separable, the perceptron algorithm will not settle on a final value of \(\tilde{w}\) , but will instead run until the maximum number of iterations is reached, without achieving perfect accuracy.

Math
In addition to regular text using the Markdown specification, you can also write mathematics, enclosed between dollar signs. The syntax for writing math is very similar to the syntax used in the \(\LaTeX\) markup language. For example, $f(x) \approx y$ renders to \(f(x) \approx y\). To place complex mathematical expressions on their own lines, use double dollar signs. For example, the expression
$$\mathcal{L}(a, b) = \sum_{i = 1}^n (ax_i + b - y_i)^2$$
renders to:
\[\mathcal{L}(a, b) = \sum_{i = 1}^n (ax_i + b - y_i)^2\;.\]

title: My Awesome CSCI 0451 Blog
text:
Feature Maps
Suppose that we were able to extract from each point its distance from the origin. In 2d, we could take a point \(\mathbf{x}\) and simply compute
\[
r^2 = x_1^2 + x_2^2\;.
\]
We could then make the classification based on the value of \(r^2\). In this data set, it looks like the classification rule that predicts \(1\) if \(r^2 < 1\) and \(0\) otherwise would be a pretty good one. The important insight here is that this is also a linear model, with linear predictor function
\[
\hat{y} = \langle \mathbf{r}, \mathbf{w} \rangle\;,
\]
and predicted labels \(\mathbb{1}[\hat{y} < 0]\).
where \(\mathbf{r}= (r^2, 1)\) and \(\mathbf{w}= (1, -1)\). This means that we can use empirical risk minimization for this problem if we just transform the features \(\mathbf{X}\) first! We need to compute a matrix \(\mathbf{R}\) whose \(i\)th row is \(\mathbf{r}_i = (r^2_i, 1) = (x_{i1}^2 + x_{i2}^2, 1)\), and then use this matrix in place of \(\mathbf{X}\) for our classification task.
The transformation \((x_1, x_2) \mapsto (x_1^2 + x_2^2, 1)\) is an example of a feature map.






Note




Definition 1 A feature map \(\phi\) is a function \(\phi:D \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^p\), where \(D\) is the set of possible data values. If \(d\in D\) is a data point, we call \(\phi(d) = \mathbf{x}\in \mathbb{R}^p\) the feature vector corresponding to \(d\). For a given feature map \(\phi\), we define the map \(\Phi:D^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n\times p}\) as
\[
\Phi(\mathbf{d}) = \left(\begin{matrix}
     - & \phi(d_1) & - \\
     - & \phi(d_2) & - \\
     \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\
     - & \phi(d_n) & - \\
\end{matrix}\right)
\]
Weâ€™ll often write
\[
\mathbf{X}= \Phi(\mathbf{d})
\]
to say that \(\mathbf{X}\) is the feature matrix for a data set \(\mathbf{d}\).



We can think of feature maps in two ways:
Feature maps can represent measurement processes. For example, maybe I am trying to classify penguins by species, based on physiological measurements. The real data is the penguin, and the measurements are how I represent that penguin with numbers. In this case, I might write my feature map as \[\phi(ðŸ§) = (\mathrm{height}, \mathrm{weight}, \text{bill length})\] Here, \(D\) is a set of many penguins \(D = \{ðŸ§_1, ðŸ§_2, ðŸ§_3, ðŸ§_4, ðŸ§_5, ðŸ§_6, ðŸ§_7\}\), and \(d\in D\) is a specific penguin. The process of transforming an object into a vector via a feature map is often called vectorization as well, especially in the context of representing digital data as vectors. We often talk about vectorizing text and images for example; this can be done using feature maps.
Feature maps can also represent data processing, which is more like our example above. There, weâ€™re taking some data thatâ€™s already a vector and turning it into a DIFFERENT vector that we think will be helpful for our learning task.

title: My Awesome CSCI 0451 Blog
text:
Feature Maps and Linear Separability
We often think of feature maps as taking us from a space in which the data is not linearly separable to a space in which it is. For example, consider the feature map
\[
(x_1, x_2) \maps_to (x_1^2, x_2^2)\;.
\]
This map is sufficient to express the radius information, since we can represent the radius as
\[
r^2 = \langle (1, 1), (x_1^2, x_2^2) \rangle\;.
\]
Letâ€™s see how this looks. Weâ€™ll again show the failed linear separator, and weâ€™ll also show a successful separator in a transformed feature space:

fig, axarr = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(8, 4))

plot_decision_regions(X, y, clf = LR, ax = axarr[0])
score = axarr[0].set_title(f"Accuracy = {LR.score(X, y)}")


X_ = X**2
LR2 = LogisticRegression()
LR2.fit(X_,y)
plot_decision_regions(X_, y, clf =  LR2, ax = axarr[1])
score = axarr[1].set_title(f"Accuracy = {LR2.score(X_,y)}")

title: My Awesome CSCI 0451 Blog
text:
Feature Maps in Practice
Going back to our example of trying to classify the two nested circles, we could just compute the radius. In practice, however, we donâ€™t really know which features are going to be most useful, and so we just compute a set of features. In our case, the square of the radius is an example of a polynomial of degree 2: \[
r^2 = x_1^2 + x_2^2\;.
\] So, instead of just assuming that the radius is definitely the right thing to compute, we more frequently just compute all the monomials of degree 2 or lower. If \(\mathbf{x}= (x_1, x_2)\), then this is
\[
\phi(\mathbf{x}_i) = (1, x_1, x_2, x_1^2, x_2^2, x_1x_2)\;.
\]
We then use a linear model to solve the empirical risk minimization problem
\[
\hat{\mathbf{w}} = \mathop{\mathrm{arg\,min}}_{w} \sum_{i = 1}^n \ell(\langle \mathbf{w}, \phi(\mathbf{x}_i) \rangle, y_i)\;.
\]
The important point to keep track of is that the new feature matrix \(\mathbf{X}' = \Phi(\mathbf{X})\) has more columns than \(\mathbf{X}\). In this case, for example, \(\mathbf{X}\) had just 2 columns but \(\Phi(\mathbf{X})\) has 6. This means that \(\hat{\mathbf{w}}\) has 6 components, instead of 2!
Letâ€™s now run logistic regression with degree-2 polynomial features on this data set. The most convenient way to make this happen in the scikit-learn framework is with at Pipeline. The Pipeline first applies the feature map and then calls the model during both fitting and evaluation. Weâ€™ll wrap the pipeline in a simple function for easy reuse.

from sklearn.preprocessing import PolynomialFeatures
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline

def poly_LR(degree, **kwargs):
    plr = Pipeline([("poly", PolynomialFeatures(degree = degree)),
                    ("LR", LogisticRegression(**kwargs))])
    return plr

def viz_plr(plr, X, y):  
    plot_decision_regions(X, y, clf = plr)
    score = plt.gca().set_title(f"Accuracy = {plr.score(X, y)}")  


#x1, x2 space with an elipse decision boundary

plr = poly_LR(degree = 2)
plr.fit(X,y)
viz_plr(plr,X,y)




Letâ€™s check the coefficients of the model:

#

Notice that two coefficients are much larger than the others, and approximately equal. These are the coefficients for the features \(x_1^2\) and \(x_2^2\). The fact that these are approximately equal means that our model is very close to using the square radius \(r^2 = x_1^2 + x_2^2\) for this data, just like weâ€™d expect. The benefit is that we didnâ€™t have to hard-code that in; the model just detected on its own the right pattern to find.
Part of the reason this might be beneficial is that for some data sets, we might not really know what specific features we should try. For example, hereâ€™s another one where a linear classifier doesnâ€™t do so great (degree 1 corresponds to no transformation of the features).

np.random.seed(123)
X, y = make_moons(200, shuffle = True, noise = 0.2)

plr = poly_LR(degree=1)
plr.fit(X,y)
viz_plr(plr,X,y)




Itâ€™s not as obvious that we should use the radius or any other specific feature for our feature map. Fortunately we donâ€™t need to think too much about it â€“ we can just increase the degree and let the model figure things out:

plr = poly_LR(degree=5)
plr.fit(X,y)
viz_plr(plr,X,y)





plr.named_steps["LR"].coef_.round(2)

array([[-0.  ,  0.14, -2.51, -2.6 , -0.83, -0.63, -0.12, -1.26,  0.2 ,
        -0.95, -0.89, -0.57, -0.13, -0.22, -0.47,  1.48, -0.72,  0.19,
        -0.32,  0.01, -0.5 ]])


Much nicer!

text:
Generalization, Feature Selection, Regularization
So, why donâ€™t we just use as many features as it takes to get perfect accuracy on the training data? Hereâ€™s an example where we get perfect accuracy on the training data:

plr = poly_LR(degree = 15, penalty = "none", max_iter = 1000000)
plr.fit(X, y)
viz_plr(plr, X, y)

#model is overfitting to noise
#effect: if we generate similar data, model won't perform well

/Users/ndang/opt/anaconda3/envs/ml-0451/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sklearn/linear_model/_logistic.py:1173: FutureWarning: `penalty='none'`has been deprecated in 1.2 and will be removed in 1.4. To keep the past behaviour, set `penalty=None`.
  warnings.warn(





Iâ€™ve had to change some parameters to the LogisticRegression in order to ensure that it fully ran the optimization procedure for this many polynomials.
The problem here is that, although this classifier might achieve perfect training accuracy, it doesnâ€™t really look like itâ€™s captured â€œthe rightâ€ pattern. This means that if we ask it to classify similar new data, itâ€™s unlikely to do as well:

X, y = make_moons(200, shuffle = True, noise = 0.2)
plr.fit(X, y)
viz_plr(plr, X, y)

/Users/ndang/opt/anaconda3/envs/ml-0451/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sklearn/linear_model/_logistic.py:1173: FutureWarning: `penalty='none'`has been deprecated in 1.2 and will be removed in 1.4. To keep the past behaviour, set `penalty=None`.
  warnings.warn(





Whoops! We have overfit: our model was so flexible that it was able to learn both some real patterns that we wanted it to learn and some noise that we didnâ€™t. As a result, when it made a prediction on new data, the modelâ€™s predictions were imperfect, reflecting the noise it learned in the training process.
In machine learning practice, we donâ€™t actually want our models to get perfect scores on the training data â€“ we want them to generalize to new instances of unseen data. Overfitting is one way in which a model can fail to generalize.
Letâ€™s do an experiment in which we see what happens to the modelâ€™s generalization ability when we increase the number of polynomial features:

import pandas as pd
np.random.seed()

degs = range(0, 11)

df = pd.DataFrame({"deg": [], "train" : [], "test" : []})

for rep in range(10):
    X_train, y_train = make_moons(100, shuffle = True, noise = .4)
    X_test, y_test = make_moons(100, shuffle = True, noise = .4)

    for deg in degs:
        plr = poly_LR(degree = deg, penalty = "none", max_iter = 1e3)
        plr.fit(X_train, y_train)

        to_add = pd.DataFrame({"deg" : [deg],
                               "train" : [plr.score(X_train, y_train)],
                               "test" : [plr.score(X_test, y_test)]})

        df = pd.concat((df, to_add))
        
means = df.groupby("deg").mean().reset_index()

plt.plot(means["deg"], means["train"], label = "training")
plt.plot(means["deg"], means["test"], label = "validation")
plt.legend()
labs = plt.gca().set(xlabel = "Degree of polynomial feature",
              ylabel = "Accuracy (mean over 20 runs)")

InvalidParameterError: The 'max_iter' parameter of LogisticRegression must be an int in the range [0, inf). Got 1000.0 instead.


We observe that there is an optimal number of features for which the model is most able to generalize: around 3 or so. More features than that is actually harmful to the modelâ€™s predictive performance.
So, one way to promote generalization is to try to find â€œthe rightâ€ or â€œthe right numberâ€ of features and use them for prediction. This problem is often called feature selection.
Another common approach to avoid overfitting is called regularization. In regularization, we actually modify the empirical risk objective function that is to be minimized. Instead of trying to minimize EquationÂ 1, we instead consider the modified objective function \[
L'(\mathbf{w}) = L(\mathbf{w}) + \lambda R(\mathbf{w})\;,
\] where \(\lambda\) is a regularization strength and \(R(\mathbf{w})\) is a regularization function that aims to influence the entries of \(\mathbf{w}\) in some way. Common choices of regularization function include the Euclidean norm \(R(\mathbf{w}) = \lVert \mathbf{w} \rVert_2^2\) and the \(\ell_1\) norm \(R(\mathbf{w}) = \sum_{j = 1}^p \lvert x_j \rvert\). To see regularization in action, letâ€™s go back to our logistic regression model with a large number of polynomial features. We can see the presence of overfitting in the excessive â€œwigglinessâ€ of the decision boundary.

X, y = make_moons(200, shuffle = True, noise = .3)

plr = poly_LR(degree = 15, penalty = "none", max_iter = 1e5)

plr.fit(X, y)
viz_plr(plr, X, y)

NameError: name 'make_moons' is not defined


Fortunately for us, we can actually use regularization directly from inside the scikit-learn implementation of LogisticRegression. We specify the penalty (the \(\ell_1\) regularization), the strength of the penalty (in the scikit-learn implementation, you specify \(C = \frac{1}{\lambda}\) so that larger \(C\) means less regularization) and the optimization solver (not all solvers work with all penalties).

#
#
#

This looks more likely to generalize! We can also increase the regularization:

#
#
#

or decrease it:

#
#
#

Like last time, we can conduct a search (often called a grid-search) to find the best value of the regularization strength for a given problem. Weâ€™ll hold fixed the number of features, and instead vary the regularization strength:

np.random.seed()

C = 10.0**np.arange(-4, 5)

df = pd.DataFrame({"C": [], "train" : [], "test" : []})

for rep in range(10):
    X_train, y_train = make_moons(100, shuffle = True, noise = .3)
    X_test, y_test = make_moons(100, shuffle = True, noise = .3)

    for c in C:
        plr = poly_LR(degree = 15, penalty = "l1", solver = "liblinear", C = c)

        plr.fit(X_train, y_train)

        to_add = pd.DataFrame({"C" : [c],
                               "train" : [plr.score(X_train, y_train)],
                               "test" : [plr.score(X_test, y_test)]})

        df = pd.concat((df, to_add))
     
means = df.groupby("C").mean().reset_index()

plt.plot(means["C"], means["train"], label = "training")
plt.plot(means["C"], means["test"], label = "validation")
plt.semilogx()
plt.legend()
labs = plt.gca().set(xlabel = "C",
              ylabel = "Accuracy (mean over 20 runs)")

Using 15 features, it looks like a regularization strength of approximately \(C = 10\) is a good choice for this problem.

import numpy as np
import random 

def f(x):
    return np.sin(x[0]*x[1])

def gradient_descent():
   w = np.random.rand(2)
   grad = np.empty(2)
   alpha = 0.001 #learning rate
   done = False 
   
   while not done: 
    grad[0] = w[1] * np.cos(w[0] * w[1])
    grad[1] = w[0] * np.cos(w[0] * w[1])
    w = w - alpha * grad
   
    if np.allclose(grad, np.zeros(len(grad))):
       done = True

    return w

text:
Choice of Batch Size in Stochastic Gradient Descent
Below is an illustration in which the choice of batch size influences how quickly the algorithm converges.


Code
LR = LogisticRegression()
LR.fit_stochastic(X, y, 0.1, 100, 50)

fig, axarr = plt.subplots(1, 2)

fig = axarr[0].plot(LR.loss_history)
axarr[0].set(xlabel = "Iteration number", ylabel = "Empirical Risk")

fig = axarr[1].plot(LR.score_history)
axarr[1].set(xlabel = "Iteration", ylabel = "Accuracy")

plt.tight_layout()
